title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The road now skirts the rocky eminences called the Hills of Braid, which command  a beautiful view of Edinburgh, with the Frith of Forth, and the shores of Fife in the background. The more northern side, called Blackford Hill, the property of Richard Trotter, Esq. of Mortonhall, is the spot mentioned in " Marmion."

title: Rambles in Europe in 1839. With sketches of prominent surgeons, physicians, medical schools, hospitals, literary personages, scenery, etc
author: Gibson, William
snippet: Under guidance, therefore, of his sons—Drs. William andAllan Thomson, two accomplished young physicians andlecturers of Edinburgh,—I walked to his cottage, pleasantly situated at the foot of Blackford Hill, and had adelightful interview with the old gentleman, if I mayapply the term to one not much above sixty. I foundhim in bed, suffering from chronic bronchitis and rheumatism, but quite cheerful, his sparkling black eye dancingto and fro, perpetually, and his attractive smile playingover his fine features as he spoke of events of formerdays; some of which he detailed to prove he had notforgotten me.

title: Curriculum Vitae: A Volume of Autobiography
author: Spark, Muriel
snippet: Like Stevenson, I used to wait at the window to witness this performance, and a few years later, when I came to possess A Child's Garden of Verses, I felt a close affinity with our long-dead Edinburgh writer, on the basis of more than one shared experience. The Braid Hills, the Blackford Hill and Pond, the Pentland Hills of Stevenson's poems, his 'hills of home' were mine, too.

title: A second series of Curious storied traditions of Scottish life
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: But the colley was not altogether satisfied ; andwdiether it was that Angus saw something in the slyeye of the dog, or that he began to dream of thesecond sight, it is certain that in a moment he wasstretched on his back among the grass, with his plaidover his face, and as still and motionless as one ofthe boulders in the Hunter's Bog. How long helay never will be known, further than that the sunwas getting beyond Blackford Hill, and he wascertainly only over the Braids, when he lay down. Never was man so changed: he rubbed his eyes;cried, " Oigh, oigh!" took a snuff; clapped Shaggon the head; promised him a gowden collar; leapedup and came down again, and did many things soapparently foolish.
